definition: to mislead the public with rumors/to delude the people with lies
to take heed of idle chatter (idiom)

sentences.english: The rumors spread throughout the school very soon.
sentences.chinese: 谣言很快就在学校里传开了。

sentences.english: They perturbed good social order with their rumours.
sentences.chinese: 他们用谣言扰乱了良好的社会秩序。

sentences.english: The quickest and simplest way to wreck any relationship is to listen to gossip.
sentences.chinese: 关联的最快最浅易的步骤就是听信谣言。

sentences.english: Sally got wind of the rumours about her.
sentences.chinese: 萨利风闻关于她的谣言。

sentences.english: The rumer turned out to be true.
sentences.chinese: 那谣言后来被证明是真的。

sentences.english: Slander , the viper , has wrongfully accused me.
sentences.chinese: 谣言这条毒蛇对我进行了恶意中伤。

sentences.english: The wildest rumours were circulating in Berlin last night, adds Reuter.
sentences.chinese: 路透社还称，昨晚在柏林有几个谣言在广泛流传。

sentences.english: I don't know how that rumor came about.
sentences.chinese: 我不知道谣言是从何来的。

sentences.english: We should not be stirred by rumors of crisis.
sentences.chinese: 我们不应该被危机的谣言弄得心烦意乱。

sentences.english: I gave my ear to what I now know was the malice of slander .
sentences.chinese: 我过去听信了谣言，现在我知道那是恶意中伤。

sentences.english: Mr. Obama is making an intense effort to rebut those claims.
sentences.chinese: 奥巴马一直在努力反驳这种谣言。

sentences.english: If the truth is the rumours bring fluster , I would tell everybody the right information in time.
sentences.chinese: 是谣言引起的慌乱，我会及时公布真实的信息。

sentences.english: Yale University has contacted Mr. Schmidt concerning these rumors.
sentences.chinese: 耶鲁大学就此谣言联系了斯密特先生。

sentences.english: Can you run the rumour back to its source?
sentences.chinese: 你能追查出这个谣言的来源吗？

sentences.english: the gossiper mates with the man herself.
sentences.chinese: 散布谣言的人自己就可以跟那个男人交配。

definition: to spread falsehoods/to increasingly distort the truth/to pile errors on top of errors (idiom)
the truth about sth/the actual facts
to sensationalize (idiom); deliberate exaggeration to scare people
(of video clips, rumors etc) to circulate on the Internet
to compile/to draw up/to fabricate/to invent/to concoct/to make up/to cook up
lit. chasing the wind and clutching at shadows (idiom); fig. groundless accusations/to act on hearsay evidence
